items.prompt: Describe the components of the Working Memory Model.
keyPoints: Central Executive: controls attention and coordinates the slave systems
Phonological Loop: processes auditory information, consists of phonological store and articulatory process
Visuo-Spatial Sketchpad: processes visual and spatial information
Episodic Buffer: integrates information from different sources and links to LTM

markingCriteria.full: Includes all four components with accurate detail

items.prompt: Explain the role of the central executive in the Working Memory Model.
keyPoints: Acts as a control system to direct attention
Coordinates activities of the slave systems
Limited capacity, can process multiple types of information

markingCriteria.full: Includes all key points with accurate detail
markingCriteria.partial: Includes 1-2 key points or lacks detail

items.prompt: Define the phonological loop and its components in the Working Memory Model.
keyPoints: Phonological Loop processes auditory information
Phonological Store: holds words heard
Articulatory Process: repeats sounds/words for memory retention

markingCriteria.full: Includes all components with accurate detail

items.prompt: A student is trying to memorize a list of words by repeatedly saying them out loud. Which part of the Working Memory Model are they using and why?
keyPoints: Using the Articulatory Process of the Phonological Loop
Involves subvocal repetition to maintain information
Helps in retaining auditory information through rehearsal

markingCriteria.full: Correctly identifies and explains the relevant component
markingCriteria.partial: Identifies the component but lacks explanation

items.prompt: Explain how the Visuo-Spatial Sketchpad might be used when navigating a new city using a map.
keyPoints: Visuo-Spatial Sketchpad processes visual and spatial information
Helps in visualizing maps and spatial relationships
Assists in planning routes and navigating spaces

markingCriteria.full: Correctly identifies and explains the component's use
markingCriteria.partial: Identifies the component but lacks detailed explanation

items.prompt: A person is recalling a past holiday experience, involving visual scenes and sounds. Which part of the Working Memory Model is involved and why?
keyPoints: Involves the Episodic Buffer
Integrates information from the visuo-spatial sketchpad and phonological loop
Links to long-term memory to form coherent episodes

markingCriteria.full: Correctly identifies and explains the component's role
markingCriteria.partial: Identifies the component but lacks detailed explanation

items.prompt: Evaluate the support for the Working Memory Model provided by dual-task studies.
keyPoints: Dual-task studies show separate processing abilities for verbal and visual tasks
Support the existence of separate slave systems
However, lack ecological validity as tasks are artificial

markingCriteria.full: Includes all evaluation points with detail
markingCriteria.partial: Includes some points but lacks depth

items.prompt: Critically assess the central executive component of the Working Memory Model.
keyPoints: Central executive is crucial but poorly defined

markingCriteria.full: Includes all critical points with detail
markingCriteria.partial: Includes some points but lacks depth

items.prompt: Discuss the limitations of the Working Memory Model in explaining memory processes.
keyPoints: Does not account for all types of memory, e.g., long-term memory
Episodic Buffer was a later addition to address limitations
Model may oversimplify the complexity of memory processes

markingCriteria.partial: Includes some limitations but lacks depth
